about_the_game:
Rigged is a game where you redraw the voting district lines in order to help the Crab Party win elections.

Your father King Crab has passed away, and the party is in dire need of a makeover. Instead of changing policy to promote the wellbeing of the sea creatures, the crabs come up with a different plan. They use the power of Gerrymandering, or the action of redrawing district lines to influence election results. Use this power that also exists in the real world to bring the Crab Party back to glory.

50+ LEVELS TO COMPLETE WITH DIFFERENT MECHANICS

The levels progress through 'world' like sections where new mechanics are introduced in each section of levels. Cities are the first new mechanic you will be introduced to. You will then come across third parties, and maybe even fourth and fifth parties. Included in the level sets are optional challenge levels for the smartest of the bunch, or at least the achievement hunters.

REAL POLICIES RELATED TO GERRYMANDERING

Levels include real policies that have been put in place to prevent gerrymandering, making your life more difficult. Includes minority districts, a method put in place with the goal of preventing the disenfranchisement of minority groups.

LEVEL EDITOR

Create your own levels using the built in level editor. Upload your levels to the workshop, and try out other creator's levels too!

COMING SOON

pc_requirements.minimum:
Minimum:
  • OS *: Windows 7
  • Processor: Dual-core CPU (e.g., Intel i3 or AMD FX)
  • Memory: 4 GB RAM
  • Graphics: Vulkan 1.0 compatible GPU (e.g., NVIDIA GTX 650, AMD HD 7750, or Intel HD Graphics 4000)
  • Storage: 500 MB available space
pc_requirements.recommended:
Recommended:
  • OS: Windows 10/11 (64-Bit)
  • Processor: Quad-core CPU (e.g., Intel i5 or AMD Ryzen 3)
  • Memory: 8 GB RAM
  • Graphics: Vulkan 1.1 compatible GPU (e.g., NVIDIA GTX 960, AMD RX 460)
  • Storage: 500 MB available space

short_description: A relaxing puzzle game about changing voting district lines in order to rig elections, an action called Gerrymandering.
